entry.title: Combined summary - Possible Solution To SM Attack
entry.summary: In November 2013, an email thread discussed a proposal to randomly choose the winning block in the case of two blocks being broadcast within a certain period. This solution was deemed fair and simple, but it raised concerns about incentivizing miners to release their blocks quickly if they were unusually low. Non-first-block-heard strategies could lead to significant increases in large reorganizations and perverse incentives. Gavin Andresen requested more analysis of the proposed selfish-mining algorithm at a specific share-of-network and gamma=0.Alice can gain an unfair advantage in the Bitcoin network by using her ability to hear of a block before all other miners do. She can withhold her blocks and only reveal them when it benefits her, giving her a head start. To counter this, a possible solution is to mine on the block with the lowest hash if N amount of blocks built of the same previous block are received within a time frame of T.In a conversation on November 5, 2013, Gregory Maxwell and Drak discussed the issue of choosing winning blocks in a fair way. Drak suggested that if two blocks were broadcast within a certain period of each other, the lower target should be chosen as the winner. However, Maxwell pointed out a flaw in this logic, stating that he would be incentivized to hurry up and release his block if his solution ended up with an unusually low number. Maxwell then proposed a two-step solution where the winner would be chosen based on the higher or lower hash value of Alice and Bob's hashes, making it a guessing game and eliminating the incentive to hurry up and release a block with an unusually low hash value.The email conversation also discusses the issue of choosing the block with the lowest hash when mining in Bitcoin. Quinn Harris suggests that it may not be the best option since both good and bad miners have an equal probability of finding a lower hash. Drak suggests making it unpredictable by choosing based on a hash of the blockhash and choosing the lowest from two. Drak suggests adding another unpredictable factor, deciding the rules of whether higher or lower wins by hashing both competing blockhashes. If the leading two hex digits are below 128 lower wins, and if above, higher wins. This should be completely unpredictable but deterministic so all the miners should end up working on the same block.
